tweet: If you feel stuck writing a sentence, get up and walk around while you think. Moving yourself makes your brain move too, and either (a) you will figure out the sentence, or (b) you will just keep walking and never stop and escape your book altogether. Either way, you win.

tweet:
ways to fix writer's block
- try turning the author on and off again
- let them talk, they might talk themselves out of their own mess
- if they're crying, put them in a bag of rice
- say "give up then" in a comforting way and watch them get back to work out of sheer spite

tweet: Being an author is both magical and strange because your book means THE WORLD to someone you've never met. Like you could have changed someone's life, written the book they love more than anything. You'll never know. It's a shy sort of magic and I love it. Books go so far.

types of writers visualising their characters
1) imagines characters' faces in detail, could fancast or do character art
2) finds random portrait on pinterest and goes with it
3) vague idea mostly vibes
4) no idea what face is, has never seen one, this book features a static blob

pros for writing

helpful tips to fix your plot holes
- lean back and squint at your writing until the problems go blurry
- just backspace that bit
- explode something so the reader looks at that instead of the hole
- have one character say "life doesn't make sense!!" and now you're covered

how to write an outline
- brain dump every cool thing that could happen in your book
- rearrange it so it mostly fits a 3-act structure
- meticulously fill in plot holes
- feel professional for 2.4 seconds
- gently lower your characters into the outline
- watch them burn it down

tweet:
writer question time! do you plot and write your books chronologically?

I plot like an absolute chaos gremlin, thinking up a middle scene and then a finale, and then hopping back to fill an earlier gap. But when writing, I never skip chapters. I write solely in order.

tweet:
what is inside a writer's brain
- new story idea that has pain and sass and no plot yet at all
- character with name but no personality
- character with personality but no name
- 3 lyrics to an annoying song
- a reminder to write a synopsis but you don't wanna
- screaming

name: C.G. Drews
description: Author of A THOUSAND PERFECT NOTES and THE BOY WHO STEALS HOUSES. Will make you laugh or cry or both. Rep by @Literary_Tara | #actuallyautistic 🏳️‍🌈🇦🇺
tweet:
People are arguing if it should be autism "awareness" or "acceptance" or "pride" but like let's have all three?! 
I want to see autistic books thrive and autistic authors feel safe and autistic readers feel seen.

name: C.G. Drews
description: Author of A THOUSAND PERFECT NOTES and THE BOY WHO STEALS HOUSES. Will make you laugh or cry or both. Rep by @Literary_Tara | #actuallyautistic 🏳️‍🌈🇦🇺
tweet:
I barely ever see disability books on bestseller lists, or on diverse rec lists, or hyped up. Quite frankly, the most famous disabled books are written by abled authors. And often it's harmful rep.

Reviews still call disabled characters: needy, whiny, immature and - unrelatable.

name: C.G. Drews
description: Author of A THOUSAND PERFECT NOTES and THE BOY WHO STEALS HOUSES. Will make you laugh or cry or both. Rep by @Literary_Tara | #actuallyautistic 🏳️‍🌈🇦🇺
tweet: In honour of #AutismAwarenessMonth, my wish is for the book community to show up for disabled authors (all kinds) all year round 🥺🙌🏻 You can't champion the phrase "read diverse books" and then blatantly leave out disabled/neurodiverse books. We notice okay. We see.

tweet: There's no "one way" to write a book. You want to speed-draft? Or write clean precise 1st drafts? Go for it. Write as a hobby, for money, solely for yourself? Write everyday or just once a week? Hire a demon to write while you lie on the carpet eating croissants? VALID all of it.

tweet:
I've written 35 complete drafts in the last 11 years!! I used to write between 4 to 7 books per yer 😳 not all GOOD, but they made me and many are exquisitely special.

......this year I edited 1 book, drafted 80% of another and cried a lot. Both life and the industry are...hard.

name: C.G. Drews

things that quietly torment readers
- trying to gush about a book out loud and realising you can't pronounce anything

- enemies to lovers to enemies again (now with feelings)

how to enjoy books correctly
- read them
- borrow them
- take photos of them

- reread your favourites
- annotate or break spines or hug fiercely
- keep them pristine
- maybe just, hear me out, enjoy books however you want

things i am weak for in books
- complicated messy all-consuming friendships
- heroes who snap and do something terrible
- villains who do this one good thing
- moody character wakes sulky and bubbly character feeds them until they're reasonable again
- platonic napping together

tweet: writing is very hard 🥺 but do you know what's even harder? NOT WRITING. Once you start, it's impossible to get away. Stories follow you around, whining pitifully until you pay attention to them. "I quit," you say and two days later...a story is just there. sHOUTING at you!!!

tweet:
reader translation guide
"I'm going to read that soon!" = will read in 6-7 years
"I need some book recs" = what i need is a nap
"this book is interesting" = it is bad
"I'm on a book ban" = preordering doesn't count
"I'm a bit behind on my TBR" = yeah backed up since 1801 help me

ways to stay excited about your writing
- make aesthetics
- daydream scenes to your epic playlists
- you want to write soft tropey scenes?! do it!
- let yourself ramble lovingly about your characters
- seriously writing is HARD so geek out over your own work, stay in love with it

reasons it's difficult to write books
- you aren't supposed to use ?! even though it's an everyday emotion
- no emojis either apparently
- writing food scenes makes you hungry
- imagining actions scenes is more fun than writing them
- you have to actually, you know, write

tweet:
how to write a book
- mix up the alphabet really well
- add in your emotional baggage on accident
- now write witty banter to cover up that mess haha
- hmm backspace a few lines
- yes that's it backspace it all
- take a snack break
- this is fine, this is how it's done

- prosper

tweet:
saying "I'm writing a book"
- cliche 
- usually untrue
- people ask what it's about and you forget your plot

saying "i'm bleeding my soul into ink on a page"
- hardcore
- authoritative
- hints that you own a sword
- people stop talking to you which is, quite frankly, helpful

how to tell if a writer is working
- they are huddled over their laptop, stabbing keys and hissing
- sitting on the floor eating cereal and saying "I'm thinking"
- staring out the window, seeing the 12th dimension
- they're cleaning the actual ceiling
- they're on twitter
